title: Welcome
text:
Postdoctoral Research Fellow (Ph.D.)


Shahram Dehghan Jabarabadi







He is a Research Fellow at the University of Padova, Italy. He is currently contributing on the PNRR P9-GRINS Growing Resilient project, entitled ‚ÄúSustainable procurement and CO2 reduction,‚Äù and the PNRR-CHANGE project, entitled ‚ÄúCHAllenges in National Governance of Environment‚Äù. He specializes in econometrics, textual analysis, and quantitative economics. His academic background includes a Ph.D.¬†in Economics (Statistical Methods) from the University of Salerno , where his thesis focused on methodological contributions related to ESG indicators, volatility modeling, and text-based approaches to financial markets. He also has completed an international visiting program to focus on Textual Analysis and Application of ESG index on the Financial Risk Management analysis in Department of Economics at the Justus Liebig University Giessen (Germany). His core research interests lie in Textual Analysis, Macroeconomics Time Series, and Risk Management. He leverages extensive programming expertise in Python, R, and MATLAB to combine time-series econometrics, natural language processing (NLP), and statistical modeling to study risk, sustainability, and the dynamics of economic systems.

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using Python
text:
Setup and Imports
This chunk imports the required Python libraries for data fetching and manipulation.
import os
import pandas as pd
import yfinance as yf

print("Libraries successfully imported.")

# Change directory to the script's location (optional for online platforms)
# os.chdir(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using Python
text:
Define Parameters and Tickers
This section sets the global time period for the data download and defines a list of financial tickers (symbols) to be retrieved. For the updated list of tickers (symbols) refers to https://finance.yahoo.com/ website.

st_date: Start date for the historical data query.
en_date: End date for the historical data query.
financial_tickers (List of symbols): A list of market assets for analysis.

# Define the global time period
st_date = '2013-01-02'
en_date = '2024-08-19'

# Define your parameters
financial_tickers = [
    '^IXIC',    # NASDAQ Composite Index (Stock Market Proxy - Stock Volatility)
    'XOP',      # SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (Energy Sector Equity Volatility)
    'NG=F',     # Natural Gas Futures
    'GLD',      # SPDR Gold Shares ETF (Gold Volatility)
    'EURUSD=X'  # Euro/USD Exchange Rate (Currency Volatility)
]

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using Python
text:
Fetching Historical Data
The yf.download() function is called to fetch the data. The settings specify daily (1d) data for the defined period.
# Download the daily data
data = yf.download(
    financial_tickers,
    start=st_date,
    end=en_date,
    interval='1d',
    auto_adjust=False, # We use auto_adjust=False here to get all standard columns
    progress=False
)

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using Python
text:
Data Cleaning and Preparation
This section processes the downloaded MultiIndex DataFrame to select only the closing prices and flatten the column structure, making it easier to work with.
# Keep only the 'Close' prices and flatten the columns.
if data.columns.nlevels > 1:
    # Select only the 'Close' column level
    data = data['Close']

    # Drop the top level which is now redundant (it would just be 'Close')
    if isinstance(data.columns, pd.MultiIndex):
        data.columns = data.columns.droplevel(0)

print("\n--- Data Information ---")
data.info()

Setup and Imports
This chunk loads the required R libraries for data fetching and manipulation.
library(quantmod) # For getSymbols() to download financial data
library(xts)      # quantmod uses the xts (eXtensible Time Series) object
library(dplyr)    # For data manipulation (optional, but good practice)

print("Libraries successfully imported.")

# Change directory 
# setwd('~')

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using R
text:
Define Parameters and Tickers
This section sets the global time period for the data download and defines a list of financial tickers (symbols) to be retrieved. For the updated list of tickers (symbols) refers to https://finance.yahoo.com/ website.

st_date: Start date for the historical data query.
en_date: End date for the historical data query.
financial_tickers (List of symbols): A list of market assets for analysis.

# Define the global time period
st_date = '2013-01-02'
en_date = '2024-08-19'

# Define your parameters
financial_tickers <- c(
    '^IXIC',     # NASDAQ Composite Index (Stock Market Proxy - Stock Volatility)
    'XOP',       # SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (Energy Sector Equity Volatility)
    'NG=F',      # Natural Gas Futures
    'GLD',       # SPDR Gold Shares ETF (Gold Volatility)
    'EURUSD=X'   # Euro/USD Exchange Rate (Currency Volatility)
)

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using R
text:
Fetching Historical Data
The getSymbols() function is called to fetch the data. The settings specify daily (1d) data for the defined period.
# Download the daily data
# auto.assign = TRUE will create separate xts objects for each ticker.
getSymbols(
    Symbols = financial_tickers,
    src = "yahoo",
    from = st_date,
    to = en_date,
    auto.assign = TRUE,
    progress = FALSE
)

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using R
text:
Data Cleaning and Preparation
This section processes the downloaded MultiIndex DataFrame to select only the closing prices and flatten the column structure, making it easier to work with.
# Combine the 'Close' prices into a single xts object.
# Cl() is a helper function in quantmod to extract the Close column from an xts object.
close_prices <- merge(
    Cl(`IXIC`),
    Cl(XOP),
    Cl(`NG=F`),
    Cl(GLD),
    Cl(`EURUSD=X`)
)

# Clean up the column names to remove the ".Close" suffix
# This is equivalent to flattening the multi-index to just the ticker name.
colnames(close_prices) <- financial_tickers

# Print Data Information and Last few rows
print("\n--- Data Information ---")
print(str(close_prices))

title: Stock Prices Data Fetch Using R
text:
Saving the Final Dataset (Optional)
This final step notes where the data would typically be saved to the CSV file path (../data/stock_assets.csv).
# Convert the xts object to a data.frame
# The index (dates) becomes the row names, and the columns are the prices.
df_prices <- as.data.frame(close_prices)

# Create a new 'Date' column from the row names (which are the dates)
df_prices$Date <- as.Date(row.names(df_prices))

# Reorder the columns to put 'Date' first (optional, but good practice)
df_prices <- df_prices[, c("Date", financial_tickers)]

# --- Optional: Save to CSV ---
write.csv(df_prices, file = '../data/stock_assets.csv', row.names = FALSE)

title: Interests
text:
Textual Analysis and Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Applying text-based methods to extract meaningful economic signals and indices:

ESG and Sustainability Indicators: Developing novel Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) metrics from textual data for evaluation and risk assessment (Core of PhD Thesis).
Consistency Index of Authorship: Designing algorithms to detect and analyze the mindset embedded in economics textbooks, with applications to macroeconomic research (Work in progress).
Dictionary-Based Methods: Creating and refining categorized text-based dictionaries to capture central ideas, particularly in multilingual economic texts (PRIN-LEXECON project).
Sentiment Analysis and Topic Modeling: Leveraging sentiment extraction and topic modeling to support risk assessment and economic forecasting.
Data Scraping: Collecting and structuring unstructured data for analysis and model development.







Econometrics and Time Series Analysis

Capturing dynamics, risk, and volatility in economic and financial data.

Macroeconomic Time Series: Modeling and forecasting macroeconomic variables, with attention to external drivers such as policy changes and commodity price fluctuations (Final chapter of PhD thesis).
Volatility Analysis: Specializing in long-term volatility modeling using mixed-frequency data and advanced GARCH-type approaches (e.g., GARCH-MIDAS).
Risk Management: Applying econometric methods to measure financial risk, including Value at Risk (VaR) and Expected Shortfall (ES).
Time-Frequency Analysis: Employing Continuous Wavelet techniques (e.g., in combination with the Ornstein‚ÄìUhlenbeck process) to study time series across multiple scales.







Programming and Statistical Modeling

Leveraging specialized software for data analysis, econometric modeling, and visualization:

Python: Skilled in natural language processing (NLP), web scraping, and general data analysis.
R: Extensive experience in econometrics, time series modeling, and risk management (VaR, ES, GARCH).
MATLAB: Applied to specialized time-frequency analysis of economic and financial time series (Wavelets).
LaTeX and Microsoft Office: Proficient in academic writing, technical documentation, and professional presentation.
